title: Russell John Flint, Jr. Pardon Details - NARA

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Russell John Flint, Jr. Pardon Details - NARA
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

A digital copy of the Indictment and the Judgment and Commitment Order for the following historical criminal case:

Defendant: Russell John Flint, Jr.
Case Number: 66-CR-216
Court: U.S. District Court for the Northern District of Illinois
Sentence Date: June 30, 1966

Specific Information Sought: I am seeking the names of the specific individuals for whom the defendant was charged with aiding and abetting the making of false Selective Service Registration Certificates.

This record is over 50 years old and is of significant historical and journalistic interest following the subject's presidential pardon on January 15, 2026. Please advise on the reproduction fees.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Anna Massoglia

communications.subject: Re: Freedom of Information Act Request: Russell John Flint, Jr. Pardon Details - NARA
communications.communication:
This is an automated reply to inform you that the National Archives and Records Administration, Transparency and Access Program (FOIA Program Area) has received your email. 

We will respond within 20 working days. Please note that submitting duplicate requests may increase wait times. If you have any questions, please follow-up with an email or you may call our office at 301-837-3190. 

You can also visit our web page at www.archives.gov/research/foia.

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: POST Separation Data
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records about police officer reasons for separation data. Any data and records that outline why an officer no longer works at a department, which departments they worked at previously, and that officer's name/POST ID
- Officer POST IDs
- Previous agencies that start from their original hire to their current/last agency
- Reason for separation (ineligibility, revocation, retirement, starting at a new agency, and other classifications collected by POST
- Employment dates

Separation reason to include: 
Resigned
Discharged
Retired
Deceased
Felony
Other
Promotion/Demotion
Involuntary Separation
Separated Pending Complaint, Administrative Charge, or Investigation for Serious Misconduct
Status Change
Did Not Complete Probation
Unknown

Please provide it in its native format: .csv, .pdf, or .json

Release records for officers hired in 1990 to today's date.  Not interested in records from officers who retired or were hired prior to that date.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Joey Scott

Please provide it in its native format: .csv, .pdf, or .json 

Release records for officers hired in 1990 to today's date. Not interested in records from officers who retired or were hired prior to that date. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes. 

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not. 

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Joey Scott 

Upload documents directly: https://www.muckrock.com/respond/2199612/” 
You will be contacted about the availability and/or provided with copies of the records in question. Pursuant to Government Code § 7922.535, POST will review your request to determine whether the request seeks disclosable public records and will respond to you within 10 days from receipt of the request as to its determination. If the request is received after business hours on a weekday, or on a weekend or holiday, the next business day will be considered the date of receipt. If the tenth day falls on a weekend or holiday, the next business day will be considered the deadline for responding to the request, pursuant to Civil Code § 11. 
You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you'll receive an email when your request has been completed. 
CA Commission on Peace Officer Standards and Training

communications.subject: Montana Freedom of Information Act Request: Elderly Care Credit Tax Statistics
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Montana Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Information related to the Elderly Care Credit from as far back as data systems will allow through 2021. Specifically, the following information, as it is available:

1) Number of returns that claimed the credit
2) Total amount of credits claimed ($)
3) If available, (1) and (2) separately by taxpayer characteristics, such as filing status, marital status, age of taxpayer, AGI range, number of dependents, etc.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Gabrielle Pepin

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Los Angeles Bureau of Street Lighting - Venice Blvd Street Lights and Permits
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

For the length of Venice Boulevard starting at Speedway and ending at Main Street:

1. Catalog or inventory information for all street lights, including details such as their identification number and location information
2. Catalog or inventory information for currently-installed streetlight pole attachments on these street lights (including but not limited to air sensors, automated license plate readers, banner advertising, communication equipment, traffic cameras, WiFi access points,  etc.)
3. All permit applications and/or agreements related to the installation of currently-installed streetlight pole attachments

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

DF

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Trevor Paul Moore (April 4, 1980 – August 7, 2021)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into comedian Trevor Paul Moore (April 4, 1980 – August 7, 2021). His death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find his New York Times obituary at the following link: https://www.nytimes.com/2021/08/09/arts/television/trevor-moore-dead.html

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. My request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

I request that I be properly classified as a media requester. I am an assistant editor at Reason Magazine who has written numerous articles on topics of public interest, and I am requesting these documents in an editorial capacity. Please contact me if you have any questions about my media status.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

communications.subject: Massachusetts Public Records Law Request: Weymouth Wednesdays
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Massachusetts Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Subject: FOIA Request for Information Regarding Traffic Enforcement Policies

 I am writing to request information under the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) related to the traffic enforcement policies of Weymouth Police Department.  Specifically, I seek documentation regarding the recent directive that instructs officers and command staff to conduct traffic enforcement exclusively on Wednesdays.

To assist in the processing of this request, please provide:

1. Any memos, emails, or internal communications from agency leadership discussing or promoting the strategy to issue tickets solely on Wednesdays.

2. Statistical data or reports that outline traffic enforcement activities, including the number of tickets issued on Wednesdays compared to other days of the week.

3. Any relevant guidelines or policies that mandate or suggest certain days for traffic enforcement over others.

4. Information on the objectives behind this strategy and whether any analysis was conducted before its implementation.

I propose a fee waiver for this request based on the public interest in transparency around law enforcement practices. This information is crucial for understanding how these policies may impact public safety and the fair application of traffic laws.

Thank you for your attention to this matter. I look forward to your prompt response.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as we believe this request is in the public interest, as suggested but not stipulated by the recommendations of the Massachusetts Supervisor of Public Records. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, and is not made for commercial usage.

I expect the request to be filled in an accessible format, including for screen readers, which provide text-to-speech for persons unable to read print. Files that are not accessible to screen readers include, for example, .pdf image files as well as physical documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

TransparentPolicing2026

communications.subject: The Missouri Sunshine Law Request: Flock Safety Records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the The Missouri Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

1) I request internal training materials for the use of "Flock Safety" tools.

2) I request policies and procedures for the use of Flock tools

3) I request any sharing agreements signed with other agencies as well as department's sharing agreement it requires other agencies to conform to.

4) I request the web address of the department's "Flock Safety" transparency portal if activated. This is a free feature of Flock. This is not an add-on or analytics subscription.

5) Lastly, I request all available audit data from the "Flock" audit tools. This should include the organization audit, network audit, and sharing report.
    A. Organization Audit in Flock.
    The report should include data logged from the period of installation to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Organization Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches done by the City.

    B. Network Audit in Flock.
    The report should include data logged from the period of installation, to the date this request is processed. Per Flock's documentation, the Network Audit is available within the Insights tab and is defined as searches of the City’s Flock network by any agency the City has shared with in the Flock System.

    C. Sharing report in Flock.
    The report should include flock networks shared with The City and networks The City is sharing its network with.

Flock maintains documentation on these reports. Flock documentation says the reports can be pulled in 31 day increments.  Flock also says that customers may want to contact support for requests longer than six months or for large accounts. If production of audit logs requires support from Flock, please declare such needs and have the City's point person on the Flock support ticket provide updates on their progress.  Please note that license plate numbers are public information or it would be unsafe to display them. Drivers would also be able to hide their plates in their trunk if they were meant to be private.  Officer usernames are similarly publicly available by many resources, such as news reports, court cases, case notes, and reports.

I request that files be supplied in their original electronic, machine readable format rather than being converted to any alternate formats. Where multiple formats are available for export, I request csv, xls, or other spreadsheet compatible formats.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Michael

communications.subject: Public Records Request :: P066023-012526
communications.communication:
Dear Michael Michael: 
Our office received your open records request pursuant to Missouri's Sunshine Law, Chapter 610, RSMo. Your request has been assigned number P066023-012526. The Patrol is committed to adhering to the Sunshine Law and to ensuring that the public obtains access to open records that are not otherwise closed by law. The Sunshine Law requires each public agency to adhere to certain standards. This letter is designed to ensure that you understand our process for fulfilling your records request. Three Business Day Notice Requirement: 
The requested records are not immediately available for dissemination or inspection. The Patrol is required to notify you that additional research time will be required to fulfill the request. This correspondence satisfies the Sunshine Law's notice requirement within the required three business day period. Section 610.023.3, RSMo. 
 Additional Research Time is Required: 
The Patrol receives thousands of open records requests each month. Our Patrol Records Division personnel are dedicated to meeting the intent of Missouri's Sunshine Law and strive to respond to each request in a timely manner. The Patrol operates in all 114 Missouri counties and the independent city of St. Louis. Accordingly, many records maintained by the agency are not centrally located within, or immediately accessible to, the Patrol's Custodian of Records in Jefferson City. Our staff must research your request and ensure that we have captured all responsive records  ̶  regardless of their location within the agency. The research process is time-consuming, but we will make every effort to expedite your request. Estimated Time for Completion: 
The majority of our requests are fulfilled within thirty business days. Some requests require additional research time due to their scope or complexity. Our team will conduct an initial review of your request. If we estimate that the request will be fulfilled within thirty business days, we will not send an updated time estimate. However, if we estimate that the request will take longer than thirty business days, we will provide an updated time estimate that provides a detailed justification for the additional research time. Billing: 
As it relates to billing, Missouri law allows the Patrol to charge fees for copies and research time. Specifically, "[r]esearch time required for fulfilling records requests may be charged at the actual cost of research time." Section 610.026, RSMo. The Missouri Supreme Court recently determined that "staff time is the time required to provide access to public records maintained on computer facilities, recording tapes or disks, videotapes or films, pictures, maps, slides, graphics, illustrations or similar audio or visual items". Gross v. Parson, 624 S.W.3d 877, 884-89 (Mo. 2021) (internal quotations omitted). 
The Patrol will never bill you for redaction time or any research time conducted by our legal staff. You will only be charged for copies and staff research time as permitted by Missouri law. Please let us know if you have questions related to the billing estimate. 
Our team will forward a bill estimate to your attention once we have calculated the permissible costs and fees. The Patrol will not provide the responsive records until receipt of payment. Section 610.026.2, RSMo. 
We appreciate your patience as we review, research, and fulfill your open records request. You can monitor the progress of your request at the link below and you will receive an email when your request has been completed. If you wish to withdraw or clarify your request, or if you have questions, please call our office at (573) 526-6146, or (573) 526-6167. 
 
Sincerely, 
Gerard G. Callahan 
Custodian of Records

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: DHS requests for assistance.
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the California Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I would like a copy of any request for assistance from the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS) or agency thereunder to the San Luis Obispo Police Department for year 2025. 
Further, I would I copy of any and all correspondence from San Luis Obispo Police Department (SLOPD) to DHS or any agency thereunder responding to any request for assistance from DHS or any agency thereunder for year 2025. 

Lastly, I would like a copy of any email or recording that is involved in deliberation "determining whether the requested assistance would be permitted under the California Values Act (Government Code § 7284.2 et seq.)" by any SLOPD supervisor involved in doing so in 2025. 

For purposes of indemnification, any deliberative process determining whether a local police department can meld itself with a federal agency in immigration raids, sweeps, and in my case, unwarranted detention, is going to be documented. I am requesting this material as a PRA request. 

"414.6 FEDERAL REQUESTS FOR ASSISTANCE
Requests by federal immigration officials for assistance from this department should be directed
to a supervisor. The supervisor is responsible for determining whether the requested assistance
would be permitted under the California Values Act (Government Code § 7284.2 et seq.)."
[San Luis Obispo Police Department Policies and Procedures manual]

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Shawn Harris

title: West Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Town of Moorefield FOIA Spring 2026

communications.subject: West Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: West Virginia Freedom of Information Act Request: Town of Moorefield FOIA Spring 2026
communications.communication:
Jessica Riley 
1511 University Avenue, P.O. Box 6010
Morgantown, WV 26506-6010
January 22, 2026 

Rick Freeman, City Clerk
Moorefield Town Hall
206 Winchester Avenue
Moorefield, WV 26836

Dear Rick Freeman, 


Under the West Virginia Freedom of Information Act, §29-B-1-1 et seq., I am requesting an opportunity to inspect or obtain copies of public records that pertain to Moorefield City’s opioid settlement funds. Specifically, I am requesting: 
- Documentation of the amount of funds the city has received from the federal opioid lawsuit settlements
- The application forms that any organization would submit to receive settlement funds
- Documentation of how much city-level funding has been awarded as of March 1, 2025, and to whom it was awarded
- Any completed application of an organization that has received settlement funds from the city
- Documentation of the process by which funds are awarded
- Any documents that contain the names of the individuals who review the funding applications and determine the awards
- Any documents that account for future plans from the city for the use of opioid settlement funds
If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me if the cost will exceed $25. However, I would also like to request a waiver of all fees in that the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public’s understanding of how the opioid settlement funds are being spent. I am a student journalist whose request is strictly for news-gathering purposes. This information is not being sought for commercial purposes. 
The West Virginia Freedom of Information Act requires a response to this request be made within five business days. If access to the records I am requesting will take longer than this amount of time, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to inspect the requested records. 
If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law. 

Thank you for considering my request. 
Sincerely, Jessica Riley 
330-978-8228
jlr00026@mix.wvu.edu

To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the West Virginia Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Communications and correspondence with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services regarding the Aug. 26, 2025, HHS letter requesting the West Virginia Department of Health remove content from the state's Personal Responsibility Education Program curricula and program materials. For reference, the letter can be found here: https://acf.gov/sites/default/files/documents/main/08.26.25-Combined-PREP-Letters.pdf.

I also request internal communications between any West Virginia Department of Health employees about the aforementioned letter. If the content changes were made, I request a copy of the material before it was changed as well as a copy of the material after it was changed.

I additionally request that, if possible, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. The requested documents will be made available to the general public free of charge as part of the public information service at MuckRock.com, processed by a representative of the news media/press and is made in the process of news gathering and not for commercial usage.

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: Rifaat al Assad
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning, relating to, or generated as a result of investigation or inquiry into Syrian military officer Rifaat Ali al Assad (22 August 1937 – 20 January 2026). His name is spelled رِفْعَتُ عَلِيِّ ٱلْأَسَدِ in Arabic. His death is widely-known and widely reported; as such, privacy concerns under FOIA Exemptions 6 and 7 are voided, as are any concerns under the Privacy Act. For example, you may find his New York Times obituary at the following link: https://www.nytimes.com/2026/01/21/world/middleeast/rifaat-al-assad-dead.html

Please conduct a search of the Central Records System, including but not limited to the Electronic Surveillance (ELSUR) Indices, the Microphone Surveillance (MISUR) Indices, the Physical Surveillance (FISUR) Indices, and the Technical Surveillance (TESUR) Indices, for both main-file records and cross-reference records of both HQ and all field offices for all relevant names, agencies, organizations, companies and events including but not limited to those cited in the previous paragraphs and/or links as well as a cross-reference with the Southern Poverty Law Center to include any information provided by the SPLC. My request includes but is not limited to 137, 157, 176, 177, 183, 184, 188, and 214 files. If previously released records are available, then I request a rolling release consisting of those records while additional records are located and processed for release.

If any part of these documents are exempt from disclosure, please be sure to review and release all reasonably segregable nonexempt portions of responsive documents, as the FOIA requires.

I request that I be properly classified as a media requester. I am an assistant editor at Reason Magazine who has written numerous articles on topics of public interest, and I am requesting these documents in an editorial capacity. Please contact me if you have any questions about my media status.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Matthew Petti

requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

**

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBI’s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBI’s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the ‘Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request tool’ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

title: Qualified Caregiving Expense Credit Tax Statistics

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: Qualified Caregiving Expense Credit Tax Statistics
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Information related to the Qualified Caregiving Expense Credit from as far back as data systems will allow through 2025. Specifically, the following information, as it is available:

1) Number of returns that claimed the credit
2) Total amount of credits claimed ($)
3) If available, (1) and (2) separately by taxpayer characteristics, such as filing status, marital status, age of taxpayer, AGI range, number of dependents, etc.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Gabrielle Pepin

communications.subject: Formal Acknowledgement | Georgia Open Records Act Request: Qualified Caregiving Expense Credit Tax Statistics
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting the Georgia Department of Revenue. Please allow this to serve as the Department's initial response to and formal acknowledgement of your open records request.

The Department will attempt to provide all requested records, but due to confidentiality law, it is possible that some items may not be disclosed. Pursuant to O.C.G.A. § 50-18-70 et seq., the Department will provide our formal response within 10 business days.

Under Georgia law, an agency may impose a reasonable charge for the search, redaction, and production or copying cost of records responsive to an Open Records Request. The time and cost will be calculated by using the hourly salary of the lowest paid employee qualified to conduct the research of an Open Records Request, with no charge for the first fifteen minutes of employee time expended. DOR will provide an estimate to the requestor if the reasonably anticipated costs for Production Tasks exceed $25 and will defer the Production Tasks until the requestor agrees to pay estimated costs.

Public Information Office
Georgia Department of Revenue
2595 Century Parkway, NE | Atlanta, GA 30345
Email: ORR@dor.ga.gov<mailto:ORR@dor.ga.gov>
Phone: 678-536-9348
dor.georgia.gov
